questions.question: Which of these is an ejective consonant?
questions.explanation: ტ [tʼ] is an ejective consonant - notice the [ʼ] symbol. თ [tʰ] is aspirated (air), and დ [d] is voiced (vibration).

questions.question: How many ejective consonants does Georgian have?
questions.explanation: Georgian has exactly six ejective consonants: კ [kʼ], პ [pʼ], ტ [tʼ], წ [tsʼ], ჭ [tʃʼ], and ყ [qʼ].

exercises.title: Match Ejectives to Their Sounds
exercises.instructions: Match each ejective consonant with its IPA symbol and description.

questions.explanation: All six ejective consonants: კ [kʼ], პ [pʼ], ტ [tʼ], წ [tsʼ], ჭ [tʃʼ], ყ [qʼ]. Notice all have the [ʼ] symbol indicating glottal closure.

exercises.title: Minimal Pairs Practice
exercises.instructions: Identify which word uses an ejective consonant.

questions.question: Which word uses an ejective: თხა [tʰxa] (goat) or ტბა [tʼba] (lake)?
questions.explanation: ტბა [tʼba] uses ejective ტ [tʼ]. თხა [tʰxa] uses aspirated თ [tʰ]. This is a perfect minimal pair showing the distinction!

questions.question: Which word uses an ejective: ქალაქი [kʰalakʰi] (city) or კაცი [kʼatsi] (man)?
questions.explanation: კაცი [kʼatsi] uses ejective კ [kʼ]. ქალაქი [kʰalakʰi] uses aspirated ქ [kʰ]. Notice the pop vs. air distinction!

exercises.title: Pronunciation Practice: Ejective Isolation
exercises.instructions: Listen and repeat each ejective consonant. Focus on producing the glottal closure and 'pop' sound.

questions.explanation: Practice the glottal closure - feel your throat close, then release with a pop. Made in the back of your throat.
Made with your lips. Close glottis, press lips together, build pressure, POP!
Tongue to alveolar ridge. Close glottis, build pressure, POP!
Ejective affricate - 'ts' sound with glottal pop. Practice slowly!
Ejective affricate - 'ch' sound with glottal pop. Like 'chair' but with a pop!
The hardest one! Made way back in your throat, almost at your uvula. Strong pop!

exercises.title: Complete Words with Ejectives
exercises.instructions: Complete each word with the correct ejective consonant based on the pronunciation.

questions.question: Complete: __აცი (man - uses ejective k):
questions.explanation: კაცი [kʼatsi] uses ejective კ [kʼ]. Remember: ejective has pop, aspirated ქ has air.

questions.question: Complete: __აპა (grandfather - uses ejective p):
questions.explanation: პაპა [pʼapʼa] uses ejective პ [pʼ]. Notice it appears twice in this word!

questions.question: Complete: __ბა (lake - uses ejective t):
questions.explanation: ტბა [tʼba] uses ejective ტ [tʼ]. Compare with თხა [tʰxa] which uses aspirated თ.

questions.question: Complete: __ყალი (water - uses ejective ts):
questions.explanation: წყალი [tsʼqʼali] uses ejective წ [tsʼ]. This word actually has TWO ejectives: წ and ყ!

exercises.title: Understanding Ejective Production
exercises.instructions: Answer questions about how ejective consonants are produced.

questions.question: What is the key mechanism for producing ejective consonants?

options.text: Closing the glottis, building pressure, then releasing with a pop

questions.explanation: Ejective consonants are produced by closing the glottis (vocal cords), building pressure in the mouth, and then releasing with a distinctive 'pop' sound. This is completely different from aspirated (air) or voiced (vibration) consonants.

questions.question: Which ejective consonant is produced the furthest back in the throat?
questions.explanation: ყ [qʼ] is a back velar ejective, made way back in the throat, almost at the uvula. It's the most challenging ejective to produce!
